user_query: Why doesn't change in accounts receivable on balance sheet match cash flow statement?
text-davinci-002_response:
Internal-1: Upon accepting an invoice from a customer, the Accounts Receivable department will post the invoice to the customer's account. The Accounts Receivable Ledger will be updated as follows: Accounts Receivable Ledger Debit Credit Customer A 100 100  Receipt of Accounts Receivable:  The following is an example of a journal entry to record the receipt of an account receivable: Accounts Receivable Debit Credit Cash 100 100 
Based on the information provided, it appears that the discrepancy between the Accounts Receivable on the Balance Sheet and the Cash Flow Statement is due to the fact that cash basis accounting is being used. Under cash basis accounting, transactions are recorded based on when the cash is received or paid, rather than when the invoice is issued or the debt is incurred. This can result in a lag between when the Accounts Receivable is first posted to the customer's account and when the cash is actually received. The rules for FICA taxes are different from regular income taxes. FICA taxes are a flat tax, meaning that everyone pays the same percentage of their income, regardless of how much they make. So, if you make $50,000 per year, you will owe $3,750 in FICA taxes (7.5% of $50,000). If you make $100,000 per year, you will still owe $3,750 in FICA taxes.
The amount of FICA taxes you owe is not affected by how much money you make from other sources. So, if you make $50,000 from your full-time job and $5,000 from freelancing, your total FICA tax liability will be $3,750 (7.5% of $50,000).
However, your employer is only responsible for withhold FICA taxes on the income you earn from your full-time job. So, if you earn $50,000 from your full-time job and $5,000 from freelancing, your employer will withhold $3,125 in FICA taxes (7.5% of $50,000). Interest on a credit card is typically calculated using a method called "average daily balance." To calculate your average daily balance, your credit card issuer will take the beginning balance of your account for each day of the billing cycle, add any new charges or payments made during that day, and then divide that number by the total number of days in the billing cycle. This number is then multiplied by the monthly interest rate to determine the amount of interest you will owe for that billing cycle. 
Some issuers may use a method called "two-cycle average daily balance" to calculate interest. This method is similar to the average daily balance method, but it uses the average daily balance from the previous billing cycle as well as the current billing cycle. Many issuers use a method called "trailing interest" to calculate interest. This method often results in a higher interest charge than the average daily balance or two-cycle average daily balance methods.

This method is similar to the trailing interest method, but it excludes new purchases and payments made during the billing cycle from the balance used to calculate interest. Some public companies choose to go public through a process called a Dutch auction. In a Dutch auction, the company and its investment bankers work together to set a price range for the IPO shares. Then, potential investors submit bids to purchase shares at or below the set price. The investment bankers then work with the company to award shares to the investors with the highest bids.
Other public companies choose to list their shares on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) or the NASDAQ Stock Exchange. In this case, the shares are priced by the market, based on supply and demand.
Still others choose to list their shares on both an exchange and through a Dutch auction.
The best place to find CSV or JSON data for publicly traded companies is on an exchange like the NYSE or NASDAQ. Alternatively, you can find this data from the SEC's EDGAR database.

user_query: What are some ways to mitigate the risks of covered calls?
text-davinci-002_response:
Covered calls are a way to mitigate the risk of owning a stock by selling call options against the stock. The capital at risk is the cost of the underlying stock minus the premium received for selling the call option. The return is the premium received for selling the call option divided by the capital at risk.
There are two measures to consider when writing covered calls. The first is to treat every covered call as a buy-write. This means that even if you already own the stock, you disregard the real cost basis and calculate from the moment you write the call, using the stock price at that time. The second measure is to use something like the XIRR function in a spreadsheet. This tracks the series as a whole, even accounting for times where there is no written call outstanding. This allows you to see the overall return of the position, including the effects of premium received and capital at risk.
It is important to note that a written put is exactly identical to a covered call at the same strike. If you tend to favor puts over CCs, ask yourself why. Just like a loaded gun, leverage isn't inherently bad, but you sure want to know when you're using it.

user_query: When can we exercice an option?

The price of the option, known as the premium, is determined by a number of factors, including the underlying security's price, the length of time until expiration, and the volatility of the underlying security. 
The holder of an options can exercise their option at any time prior to expiration. 
When the holder exercises their option, they are buying or selling the underlying security at the strike price. 
If a call option is exercised, the holder will buy the underlying security at the strike price. If a put option is exercised, the holder will sell the underlying security at the strike price.
